article.title: Apollo_10

template.arg: Apollo 10's Lunar Module, ''Snoopy'', approaches the Command/Service Module ''Charlie Brown'' for redocking

[[Apollo Command/Service Module|Apollo CSM]]-106
[[Apollo Lunar Module|Apollo LM]]-4

Left to right: Cernan, Stafford, Young

article.paragraph: Apollo 10was the fourth manned mission in theUnited StatesApollo programApollo space program, and the second (afterApollo 8) to orbit theMoon. Launched on May 18, 1969, it was theList of Apollo mission typesF mission: a "dress rehearsal" for the firstMoon landing, testing all of the components and procedures, just short of actually landing. TheApollo Lunar ModuleLunar Module(LM) came to withinconvert8.4nmikmusof thelunar surface, the point where the powered descent to the lunar surface would begin.cite webhttp://er.jsc.nasa.gov/seh/Ap10.htmlMission Report: Apollo 10June 17, 1969NASAMR-4September 11, 2012Its success enabled the first landing to be attempted onApollo 11in July, 1969.

According to the 2002Guinness World Records, Apollo 10 set the record for the highest speed attained by a manned vehicle at 39,897 km/h (11.08 km/s or 24,791 mph) during the return from the Moon on May 26, 1969.

Due to the use of their names ascall signs, thePeanutscharactersCharlie BrownandSnoopybecame semi-official mascots for the mission.cite webhttp://science.ksc.nasa.gov/mirrors/images/images/pao/AS10/10075138.jpgReplicas of Snoopy and Charlie Brown decorate top of console in MCCMay 28, 1969NASANASA Photo ID: S69-34314June 25, 2013Photo description availablehere.PeanutscreatorCharles Schulzalso drew some special mission-related artwork forNASA.
article.heading: Crew
Backup crew
Support crew
Flight directors
Crew notes
article.paragraph: Apollo 10 was the first of only two Apollo missions with an entirely flight-experienced crew (the other beingApollo 11).Thomas P. Staffordhad flown onGemini 6AGemini 6andGemini 9AGemini 9;John Young (astronaut)John W. Younghad flown onGemini 3andGemini 10, andEugene CernanEugene A. Cernanhad flown with Stafford on Gemini 9.

In addition, Apollo 10 marked the onlySaturn Vflight fromKennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39Launch Complex 39B, as preparations for Apollo 11 at LC-39A had begun in March almost immediately afterApollo 9's launch.

They were also the only Apollo crew all of whose members went on to fly subsequent missions aboardApollo (spacecraft)Apollo spacecraft: Young later commandedApollo 16, Cernan commandedApollo 17and Stafford commanded the US vehicle on theApolloSoyuz Test Project.

The Apollo 10 crew holds the distinction of being the humans who have traveled to the farthest point away from home, someconvert408950kmnmiusfrom their homes and families inHouston.cite webhttp://www.scilogs.eu/en/blog/spacetimedreamer/2009-06-06/far-away-from-homeFar Away From HomeHoltkampGerhardJune 6, 2009SpaceTimeDreamerSciLogsBlog20 September 2011While most Apollo missions orbited the Moon at the sameconvert111kmnmiusfrom the lunar surface, timing makes this distinction possible as the distance between the Earth and Moon varies by approximatelyconvert43000kmnmius(betweenperigeeandapogee) throughout the year, and the Earth's rotation make the distance to Houston vary by anotherconvert12000kmnmiuseach day. The Apollo 10 crew reached the farthest point in their orbit around the far side of the Moon at approximately the same time Earth had rotated around putting Houston nearly a full Earth diameter away. TheApollo 13crew holds the distinction of being the farthest any human has traveled from the Earth's surface.#GlendayGlenday 2010, p. 13

By the normal rotation in place during Apollo, the backup crew would have been scheduled to fly on Apollo 13. However,Alan Shepardwas given the Apollo 13 command slot instead.Gordon CooperL. Gordon Cooper, Jr., Commander of the Apollo 10 backup crew, was enraged and resigned from NASA. Later, Shepard's crew was forced to switch places withJim Lovell's tentativeApollo 14crew.#ChaikinChaikin 2007, pp. 34748

Deke Slaytonwrote in his memoirs that Cooper andDonn F. Eiselewere never intended to rotate to another mission as both were out of favor with NASA management for various reasons (Cooper for his lax attitude towards training and Eisele for incidents aboardApollo 7and anaffair#Extramarital affairextramarital affair) and were assigned to the backup crew simply because of a lack of qualified manpower in theChief of the Astronaut OfficeAstronaut Officeat the time the assignment needed to be made. Cooper, Slayton noted, had a very small chance of receiving the Apollo 13 command if he did an outstanding job with the assignment, which he did not. Eisele, despite his issues with management, was always intended for future assignment to theApollo Applications Program(which was eventually cut down to only theSkylabcomponent) and not a lunar mission.#Slayton & CassuttSlayton & Cassutt 1994, p. 236
article.heading: Mission parameters
Earth orbit
Lunar orbit
LM CSM docking
LM closest approach to lunar surface
article.paragraph: On May 22, 1969 at 20:35:02 UTC, a 27.4 second LM descent propulsion system burn inserted the LM into a descent orbit ofconvert60.9by8.5nmikmso that the resulting lowest point in the orbit occurred about 15 from lunar landing site 2 (the Apollo 11 landing site). The lowest measured point in the trajectory wasconvert47400ftkmabove the lunar surface at 21:29:43 UTC.cite bookBrooksCourtney G.GrimwoodJames M.SwensonLoyd S., Jr.Foreword by [[Samuel C. Phillips]]Chariots for Apollo: A History of Manned Lunar Spacecrafthttp://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4205/cover.htmlJanuary 29, 2008NASA History Series1979Scientific and Technical Information Branch, NASAWashington, D.C.978-0-486-46756-6466444979001042NASA SP-4205''Apollo 10:'' The Dress Rehearsalhttp://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4205/ch12-7.html
article.heading: Mission highlights
article.paragraph: File:Apollo 10 Earthrise.ogvthumbEarthrise video captured by Apollo 10 crew on 1969This dress rehearsal for a Moon landing brought theApollo Lunar Moduletoconvert8.4nmikmfrom the lunar surface, at the point where powered descent would begin on the actual landing. Practicing this approach orbit would refine knowledge of theLunar orbit#Perturbation effectslunar gravitational fieldneeded to calibrate the powered descent guidance systemCite journalEylesDonTales From the Lunar Module Guidance Computerhttp://klabs.org/history/apollo_11_alarms/eyles_2004/eyles_2004.htmNASA Office of Logic DesignFebruary 6, 2004to withinconvert1nmikm(LR altitude update lock)ElucidateSeptember 2014needed for a landing. Earth-based observations, unmannedspacecraft, andApollo 8had respectively allowed calibration to withinconvert200nmikm,convert20nmikm, andconvert5nmikm. Except for this final stretch, the mission went exactly as a landing would have gone, both in space and on the ground, putting NASA'sflight controllersand extensive tracking and control network through a rehearsal.

Shortly aftertrans-lunar injection, the Command/Service Module (CSM) separated from theS-IVBstage, turned around, and docked its nose to the top of the Lunar Module (LM) still nestled in the S-IVB. The CSM/LM stack then separated from the S-IVB for the trip to the Moon.
Apollo 10 was the first mission to carry acolor televisioncamera inside the spacecraft, and made the first live color TV transmissions from space.

Upon reaching lunar orbit, Young remained alone in theApollo Command/Service Module#Command Module (CM)Command Module(CM)Charlie Brownwhile Stafford and Cernan flew separately in the LMSnoopy. The LM crew demonstrated their craft's radar and engines, rode out a momentary gyration in the lunar lander's motion (due to a faulty switch setting), and surveyed the Apollo 11 landing site in theSea of Tranquility. The ascent stage was loaded with the amount of fuel it would have had remaining if it had lifted off from the surface and reached the altitude at which the Apollo 10 ascent stage fired. The fueled LM weighedconvert30735lbkg, compared toconvert33278lbkgfor the Apollo 11 LM which made the first landing.cite bookOrloffRichard W.Apollo by the Numbers: A Statistical Referencehttp://history.nasa.gov/SP-4029/SP-4029.htmJune 25, 2013NASA History SeriesFirst published 2000September 2004NASA History Division, Office of Policy and PlansNASAWashington, D.C.0-16-050631-X00061677NASA SP-2000-4029Launch Vehicle/Spacecraft Key Factshttp://history.nasa.gov/SP-4029/Apollo_18-12_Launch_Vehicle-Spacecraft_Key_Facts.htmStatistical Table 18-12.Historian Craig Nelson wrote that NASA took special precaution to ensure Stafford and Cernan would not attempt to make the first landing. Nelson quoted Cernan as saying "A lot of people thought about the kind of people we were: 'Don't give those guys an opportunity to land, 'cause they might!' So the ascent module, the part we lifted off the lunar surface with, was short-fueled. The fuel tanks weren't full. So had we literally tried to land on the Moon, we couldn't have gotten off."#NelsonNelson 2009, p. 14NASA official historymakes it plain that there was never a chance for "Snoopy" to land and take off again. "There had been some speculation about whether or not the crew might have landed, having gotten so close. They might have wanted to, but it was impossible for that lunar module to land. It was an early design that was too heavy for a lunar landing, or, to be more precise, too heavy to be able to complete the ascent back to the command module. It was a test module, for the dress rehearsal only, and that was the way it was used. Besides, the discipline on the Apollo program was such that no crew would have made such a decision on its own in any event."In his own memoir, Cernan wrote "Our lander, LM-4...was still too heavy to guarantee safe margins for a moon landing."Cernan, p.184

Upon separation of the descent stage and ascent engine ignition, the Lunar Module began to roll violently due to the crew accidentally duplicating commands into the flight computer which took the LM out of abort mode, the correct configuration for this maneuver.YouTubefsObsxU08ys"Astronaut Gene Cernan Interview on Apollo 10 - (December 23, 2009)"noThe live network broadcasts caught Cernan and Stafford uttering several expletives before regaining control of the LM. Cernan has said he observed the horizon spinning eight times over, indicating eight rolls of the spacecraft under ascent engine power. While the incident was downplayed by NASA, the roll was just several revolutions from being unrecoverable, which would have resulted in the LM crashing into the lunar surface.

Splashdown (spacecraft landing)Splashdownoccurred in the Pacific Ocean on May 26, 1969 at 16:52:23 UTC, approximatelyconvert400nmikmeast ofAmerican Samoa. The astronauts were recovered by theUSS Princeton (CV-37)USS ''Princeton'', and subsequently flown toPago Pago International AirportinTafuna, American SamoaTafunafor a greeting reception, before being flown on aLockheed C-141 StarlifterC-141cargo plane toHonolulu.
article.heading: Hardware disposition
article.paragraph: The LMSnoopy's descent stage was left in orbit, but eventually crashed onto the lunar surface because of the Moon's non-uniform gravitational field; its location was not tracked.

After being jettisoned,Snoopy'sascent stage engine was fired to fuel depletion, sending it on a trajectory past the Moon into aheliocentric orbit.cite webhttp://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/apollo/missions/apollo10.htmlApollo 10RybaJeanneNASAJune 26, 2013cite webCurrent locations of the Apollo Command Module Capsules (and Lunar Module crash sites)http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/lunar/apolloloc.htmlApollo: Where are they now?NASA27 December 2014All other ascent stages were either left in lunar orbit to eventually crash, intentionally steered into the Moon to obtain readings from seismometers placed on the lunar surface, or else burned up in Earth's atmosphere.Snoopy's ascent stage orbit was not tracked after 1969, and its current location is unknown. In 2011, a group of amateur astronomers in the UK started a project to search for it.cite newsThe Search for Apollo 10's 'Snoopy'MarkThompsonhttp://news.discovery.com/space/apollo-10-search-snoopy-astronomy-110919.htmlDiscovery News[[Discovery Communications]]September 19, 2011June 26, 2013cite newsThe Search for 'Snoopy': Astronomers & Students Hunt for NASA's Lost Apollo 10 ModuleRobert Z.Pearlmanhttp://www.space.com/13010-snoopy-nasa-lost-apollo-10-lunar-module-search.htmlSPACE.comSeptember 20, 2011June 26, 2013

The Command ModuleCharlie Brownis currently on loan to theScience Museum (London)Science Museumin London, where it is on display.Charlie Brown'sApollo Command/Service Module#Service Module (SM)Service Module(SM) was jettisoned just before re-entry and burned up in the Earth's atmosphere.

After Apollo 10, NASA required astronauts to choose more "dignified" names for their command and lunar module. The requirement was unenforceable: Apollo 16 astronauts Young, Mattingly and Duke choseCasper, as inCasper the Friendly Ghost, for their Command Module name. The idea was to give children a way to identify with the mission by usinghumor.cite newsYoung Takes Rover for a SpinMichaelShinaberyhttp://moonandback.com/2012/09/30/young-takes-rover-for-a-spin-this-week-in-space-history/September 30, 2012moonandback.comMoonandback Media LLCSacramento, CAPart 2 of 3yJuly 11, 2013cite webhttp://dreamsofspace.blogspot.com/2010/12/apollo-16-poster-with-casper-friendly.htmlApollo 16 poster with Casper the Friendly Ghost (1972)SissonJohnDecember 13, 2010Dreams of SpaceBlogJuly 11, 2013

After thetranslunar injectioninsertioninto trans-Lunar orbit, theS-IVBSaturn IVBthird stagebecame a:Category:Derelict satellites in heliocentric orbitderelictspace debrisobjectwhere it would continue toheliocentric orbitorbit the Sunfor many years.asof2015, it remains in orbit.cite webSaturn S-IVB-505N - Satellite Informationhttp://www.heavens-above.com/SatInfo.aspx?satidSatellite databaseHeavens-AboveSeptember 23, 2013
article.heading: Mission insignia
article.paragraph: File:Apollo 10 Flown Silver Robbins Medallion (SN-70).jpgthumbApollo 10 space-flown silverNASA space-flown Robbins medallions of the Apollo missionsRobbins medallionThe shield-shaped emblem for the flight shows a large, three-dimensionalRoman numeralsRoman numeralX sitting on the Moon's surface, in Stafford's words, "to show that we had left our mark." Although it did not land on the Moon, the prominence of the number represents the significant contributions the mission made to the Apollo program. A CSM circles the Moon as an LM ascent stage flies up from its low pass over the lunar surface with its engine firing. The Earth is visible in the background. On the mission patch, a wide, light blue border carries the word APOLLO at the top and the crew names around the bottom. The patch is trimmed in gold. The insignia was designed by Allen Stevens ofRockwell International.cite webEdHengeveldhttp://www.collectspace.com/news/news-052008a.htmlThe man behind the Moon mission patches[[collectSPACE]]May 20, 2008July 18, 2009"A version of this article was published concurrently in theBritish Interplanetary Society'sSpaceflight (magazine)Spaceflightmagazine." (June 2008; pp. 220225).
